questions.question: Two stationary blocks, Block A and Block B, sit on a frictionless horizontal plane. Block A has a mass three times that of Block B. A constant horizontal force $F$ is applied to Block A, pushing it across a distance $d$. The force is then removed and applied to Block B, pushing it across the exact same distance $d$. At the moment each block has traveled the distance $d$, which of the following is true?
In a perfectly inelastic one-dimensional collision, what initial condition is required for the system to lose 100% of its kinetic energy?
options: The objects must have identical masses.
The objects must have identical speeds but move in opposite directions.
The objects must have momenta of equal magnitude and opposite directions.
It is physically impossible to lose all kinetic energy in any collision.
questions.explanation: 100% KE loss means final velocity = 0 ⇒ total momentum = 0.

questions.question: Which of the following equations correctly expresses the kinetic energy ($K$) of an object in terms of its mass ($m$) and its momentum ($p$)?

A 50 g ping-pong ball is traveling at a high speed when it strikes a stationary 2.5 kg steel sphere in a one-dimensional elastic collision. The ping-pong ball rebounds in the opposite direction. After the interaction, how do the magnitude of momentum ($p$) and the kinetic energy ($K$) of the ping-pong ball compare to those of the steel sphere?
options: The ping-pong ball has a smaller magnitude of momentum and more kinetic energy.
The ping-pong ball has a larger magnitude of momentum and less kinetic energy.
The ping-pong ball has the same magnitude of momentum and less kinetic energy.
The ping-pong ball has a smaller magnitude of momentum and less kinetic energy.
questions.explanation: Light object rebounds with nearly same speed, so its $p$ is smaller but retains most KE.

questions.question: An observer on a riverbank sees a boat with two passengers drifting downstream at a constant velocity $v$. One passenger at the front of the boat throws a heavy gear bag toward the passenger at the rear. While the bag is in the air—and neglecting any water resistance—the velocity of the boat is:
questions.explanation: Throwing bag backward increases boat's forward velocity by momentum conservation.

questions.question:
A moving puck on an air hockey table undergoes a collision with a second puck that is initially stationary. Neglecting friction, which of the following outcomes is/are possible immediately after the impact?

(I) The first puck comes to a complete stop while the second puck moves away.
(II) Both pucks come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: I is possible (equal masses elastic). II would violate momentum conservation.

questions.question: A 2.0 kg object moving at 4.0 m/s collides elastically with a stationary 6.0 kg object. After the collision, the 2.0 kg object moves in the opposite direction at 2.0 m/s. What is the velocity of the 6.0 kg object after the collision?
In a two-dimensional collision, momentum is conserved:
options: only in the direction of the initial velocity
questions.explanation: Momentum is a vector, conserved in all directions independently.

questions.question: A 3.0 kg object has a kinetic energy of 54 J. What is its momentum?
Two objects of unequal mass undergo a perfectly inelastic collision. Which statement is true?
options: The final velocity is closer to the initial velocity of the more massive object.
The final velocity is the average of the initial velocities.
The final velocity is zero regardless of initial conditions.
questions.explanation: $v_f = (m_1v_1 + m_2v_2)/(m_1+m_2)$ is a weighted average favoring the more massive object.
